title: "We Realize Potential in Dominion"
body:
"We realize that people like this map, but not as much as we'd like.

We realize that we can change that, and make it a lot more open for other players. We realize that it can be improved and that we can make players enjoy it much more, and truly make it a vibrant game mode.

So fuck you. 

We're taking it away."

-Riot Games

Wunna play league? Get in a lane  - Riot 2016

ARAM isn't exactly everyone laning in the same lane...

Well, technically that's exactly what it is, sure. 

BUT you start at level 3 with more gold than usual (so the hardest part of laning phase is over). CS doesn't matter very much at all because there are so many more kills and more passive gold. 

ARAM is a permanent teamfight. No one calls teamfighting to siege an inhibitor turret on summoner's rift "laning". Just my opinion...

Now, if you want to say it's the only mode where your focus is not on destroying towers via sieging or split pushing, then I'd agree.

ARAM's more laning and sieging than it is teamfighting.

Early-game ARAM, you stand around, grab some CS, throw some harass, maybe land a couple hits on the enemy tower, and hide under your tower if you're losing. That's essentially laning. Mid- and late-game, you dance around, throw out some poke, maybe land a few hits on the enemy tower, and finally fight when someone gets caught out of position. That's standard sieging. 

Unless you've got some strange teamcomps or some massively bloodthirsty players, you don't normally get teams constantly rushing into each other.

Depends on what you're going for. I typically prefer "measured aggression" over "bloody deathmatch." Constant brawling is certainly nice occasionally, but it gets awkward if you're doing it regardless of teamcomp or cooldowns.
You describe low elo aram games, higher elo aram games are bloodthirsty, unless you have 3-5 1k+ range poke mages on both teams, teams bump into eachother every 1-2 levels (waiting on R's cooldown)

Are you speaking from personal experience of high-MMR games? Because from what I can tell, we're both roughly in the same MMR bracket.

Regardless, ult cooldowns are generally at least a minute early-game. Assuming a fight breaks out every minute, that's still roughly 30 seconds of posturing before the fight starts and 10-20 seconds of pushing while people are dead. Plus, there's the time spent pre-6.

Both played + spectated.

I used to have close to 100 wins over losses, i stopped playing for some years, came back lost about 50 games and I'm bit below 50 wins over losses now and passive games are more common as your elo decreases. The reason is simple, the better and more familiar people get at the game or with their champions, the more confident and cocky they behave. They know how much damage they deal with their champion, and they will go for the kill every time you are out of position, and they will kill you, unless you make some outstanding play.

An average high elo aram game has maybe a score of 50-70 kills for each team by the 20 minutes mark.

That reason's not quite as simple as you think. Sure, better players are more likely to punish mistakes, but they're also less likely to make mistakes.

Regardless, we're getting a bit off-track. I didn't say ARAM games are passive; I said they're not constant teamfights. Teamfights may occur often, but there's still a significant amount of time spent posturing before teamfights, waiting for cooldowns, and pushing/regrouping after teamfights, waiting on death timers.

Being out of position =/= making a mistake.

With the introduction of snowball, you are essentially always out of position, when the danger zoned used to be 500-ish range (dash/flash range), it's now 500-1000+ range, which is where everyone is regardless of skill.

A lot of aram games go like this = A gets caught by B and dies, B is now out of position and gets caught and get killed C + D, C+D are now out of position and get jumped on by  E+F and die, A and B who died some time ago are now back and jump on E+F, etc. Hence I quote you, no real posturing waiting pushing regrouping..

The waiting on cooldown thing only really happens when one side is losing significantly, if you got stomped the past 3 fights and the score is 10-25, you most likely don't want to fight much again without your R to maximize your chances. When it's more even, you don't wait for cooldowns.

But again, that kinds of depends on the team compositions, if you have lots of poke and stuff on both teams, fights will consist of ppl throwing stuff in eachother direction more than any real brawling.

"Fewer than 0.5% of players actively play Dominion and we’re aware some number of even that small population is still bots. We haven’t been supporting Dominion, and we’ve trapped ourselves in a vicious cycle where the queue isn’t large enough to warrant major attention, but falls prey to bugs and periods of imbalance from the introduction of new champs and items (which then drives down the size of the queue, and so on)."

Really? Zero point five percent. Nobody plays it. I would like to see it getting support and a playerbase, but...it's just not there.

Unfortunately. I'm not fully aware of the mode's history, but at some point, it was a new game mode, and over time, it failed to attract enough attention to merit devoting resources to its maintenance. I'm not clear on whose fault that is, exactly. Whether it was poorly advertised, whether Riot failed to maintain it when it was getting attention, whether it simply never had enough of a playerbase at all...I'm not sure. It's sad, though. I think the game could use a little more variety, and objectives different from "push through towers and destroy the nexus" are probably the best way to achieve that.

It's really Riot's. They promised ranked queues, even had them ready but just needed to turn them on (according to Riot). Over time, people got tired of trying to find games on it and seeing no support, so they quit playing it.
